That's pretty much "the" book to have for waki-Goto.  It's a very useful resource and pretty much a must-have for fittings researchers.

Jim


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Gordon Robson 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 6:23 PM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko


  Thanks Michael, a highly cogent reply. I don't have this book, but I think I
  should get it.

  Gordon

  -----Original Message-----
  From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On

  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko

  Right on both counts Gordon...The book is:

  STUDIES IN KYO GOTO
  Kasahara Koju, Akimoto Shigeo (1988)
  A unique text for presenting written survey in both English and 
  Japanese of the waki-Goto schools, the fifteen branch families of the 
  mainline Goto masters. Tosogu are shown full size with enlarged, 
  detail photographs of inscriptions. This English translation also 
  extends to the captions and descriptions accompanying each plate.

  Picture and complete description at http://satcho.
  <http://satcho.com/Tosogu.htm> com/Tosogu.htm

  Michael

  satcho.com
  http://www.satcho. <http://www.satcho.com> com Specialists in books related
  to the study & 
  appreciation of the Japanese sword as art. 
  _______________________________________________

  yahoogroups.com, ROBSON Gordon <robsongo@...> wrote:
  >
  > Hi Ron,
  > 
  > My understanding is that Kyo-Kinko is the new name for Waki-Goto. 
  This would 
  > make them a grab bag like Ko-Kinko or even Shoami. Their dates are 
  post-Ko-
  > Kinko, so early Edo to Bakumatsu. There is a Kyo-Kinko book out 
  there. I think the 
  > title is Kyo-Kinko no Kenkyu (research into Kyo-Kinko) or something 
  like that. Jim 
  > is probably better up on this stuff then I am.
  > 
  > On on different note, good luck to Harry. Honto ni gambatte kudasai!!
  > 
  > Gordon
